data.title: BoC Signals Its Rate Cut Cycle May Be Finished
data.description:
The Bank of Canada cut its key interest rate by another 25 basis points, but also signaled that it may be on hold going forward. Andrew Kelvin, Head of Canadian Rates and Global Rates Strategy with TD Securities tells MoneyTalk the expected Federal Budget may help the BoC stay on the sidelines.

Transcript

Greg Bonnell: Bank of Canada has cut its interest rate by another 25 basis points, but Governor Tiff Macklem sending some strong signals that this may be the end of this cutting cycle. Joining us now to discuss, Andrew Kelvin, Managing Director and Head of Canadian and Global Rates Strategy at TD Securities.

Great to have you back on the program.

Andrew Kelvin: Thank you for having me.

Greg Bonnell: Strong indication here. I know this was the call from TD Securities heading into this. We get a 25 basis point cut, and that's it. That's the end. They've hit their terminal rate, he's indicating pretty strongly there. What would it take to move them off that sideline?

Andrew Kelvin: Yeah, I will say I was a little bit surprised they were as explicit as they were about expecting that they were done with this easing cycle at this level. I would have thought they would have been a little bit more cagey about it, maybe preserve a little bit more optionality for future meetings. But I think the fact that they were so transparent about how they're viewing the future policy path tells you that there's a very, very high bar for them to cut rates again in December. Presumably, this has some sort of relationship to the upcoming federal budget, which is expected broadly to be stimulative. And it would make sense if you're the central bank to not be easing immediately after a rather stimulative budget.

Now, in order to get them off of this hold that they've sort of communicated they're in, the answer is really simple. The governor was saying that if conditions change, they will reevaluate their path, which is what you would both hope and expect. December, I feel pretty comfortable with the idea that December is a hold. They would not have been as explicit in their communication if they thought there was a reasonable chance of a December cut.

And again, it has that sort of proximity to the budget. Even January, it's not clear to me that we're going to have a good indication as to what the stimulative impacts of that budget will be. If the economy is flagging a little bit in January, we will still have the potential boost coming from announced stimulus into 2026 to comfort policymakers.

But if we get into the spring-- so I'm really looking at March, April, June meetings-- and growth is not above its trend rate, if we're still seeing excess capacity in the economy grow, at that point the Bank of Canada, I think, will have to reconsider if this is, in fact, the floor for interest rates in this cycle. And if it turns out that the drag on the economy from the trade dispute with the United States is a little bit worse, if trading conditions with the United States become worse than they are today, that would be something that would cause them to reconsider.

And when I say worse than they are today, I'm not talking about just that sort of presumptive 10% additional reciprocal tariff. I'm talking about something that's more broadly punitive for a wider swath of the Canadian economy.

Greg Bonnell: Seem to be in a bit of a tough place because they are recognizing, of course, that they can't solve a trade war just through monetary policy. But sometimes a trade war can send prices higher, but a weaker economy, they think all of that weighs out, keeps prices in check. Are they being a little too optimistic on inflation being contained, considering everything we're facing?

Andrew Kelvin: The reason-- I think it's actually a very reasonable set of forecasts they have. And I would say that on both the growth and inflation side. We can't solve a change in our trading relationship with monetary policy. What monetary policy can do is smooth that adjustment. It can make that adjustment less painful, which is why these sorts of moves are appropriate in my mind.

In terms of how inflation is going forward, I think the reason why I'm pretty comfortable with the idea inflation will be contained around 2%-- I never want to put a firm 2.0, so somebody can point their finger at me and say I'm wrong if it's 2.1.

To me, a perhaps overlooked thing in the structural change the Canadian economy is going under right now is the change in population growth. We had obviously very strong population growth in recent years, which is one of the factors that helped contribute to rising rents, rising shelter prices broadly. If we are going to remain in an environment where population growth is very, very weak, close to 0, we shouldn't have those same upward pressures on shelter prices. We shouldn't have those same upward pressures on rents.

And shelter's a huge part of the CPI basket. So if we're going to be in an environment where population growth is very weak, that should prevent runaway shelter price inflation. And that in and of itself should be enough to keep inflation around 2%.

Greg Bonnell: Now, you mentioned the structural changes that we're undergoing because of the trade tensions and how the relationship is probably not going to be the same going forward. Well, it's not the same right now with the US. Governor Macklem mentioned it as well. Once we get through these structural changes, what does our economy look like on the other side?

Andrew Kelvin: So it's probably an economy where the level of activity in the economy is just lower than it otherwise would have been. The way I tend to think about these things is you have a drag on growth in year 1 and 2. And even if you see growth return to its previous levels, you still have this sort of permanent gap between where the level of activity could have been and where you are now. And additionally, they did highlight that they look at these changing trade relationships as something that will drag on potential GDP. So having weaker terms of-- weaker trading conditions, weaker ability to trade with the US, less open market access is something that will drag potentially permanently on Canadian growth in their mind.

So they see us transitioning to a lower-growth economy due to the fact that we will have less open trading conditions with the US going forward, just assuming that the current conditions move forward. If we are able to strike some sort of a grand bargain and go back to the world the way it was, in November, just in terms of what the actual tariffs charged are, what the actual market access is, obviously, a lot of that drag sort of disappears, and we can return to that previous economic trajectory.

One point I would just make, though, is one of the values of a trade deal is it provides certainty. Businesses can look at the trade deal, trust that the terms of market access will remain constant, and make investments and decisions with the long term in mind. Going forward, even if we get a deal in the next day, week, month, quarter, year, whatever--

Greg Bonnell: We had a deal under the first Trump administration, right?

Andrew Kelvin: So yeah, pick your time horizon. I don't think people will be quite as willing to just accept that this will be a long-term deal, which they were in the first USMCA. I think when the first USMCA was signed, people had assumed that that deal would hold. And I'm quite certain-- I probably came on your show and said in 2024, I was like, well, Donald Trump signed USMCA one, so surely he won't tear it up. And then fast forward to today and he has largely moved away from that deal.

So it is something where we probably never fully unring that bell. It probably does speak to an economy where, absent other positive developments, we're in a bit more of a slow-growth environment, which is probably why you see the federal government so focused on taking measures to boost productivity.

Greg Bonnell: Talk about that. I mean, that puts a lot of pressure on next week's federal budget, doesn't it, to show us something that this economy needs? What do we need to see from that budget?

Andrew Kelvin: The budget is probably having too much asked of it at this point. The federal government is in a fairly enviable position, just in that 15 to 20 years of reasonably responsible fiscal policy in Canada. I mean that the governments over in the post-pandemic era have had a lot of fiscal room. Our net federal debt to GDP is quite low. So this government can come out with a 2, 2.5% budget deficit as a share of GDP without really roiling markets. And I think markets are quite positioned for what could be quite a large deficit in this upcoming budget.

The problem I think the government faces here is that a lot of the measures that they would like to take to boost productivity-- cutting red tape. Their first bill, the first signature bill they passed when they came into parliament before the summer recess was about streamlining projects of national importance. And that's all well and good, cutting red tape is all-- I've never heard an argument for red tape. I'm sure it exists, but no one's ever said it to me.

That sort of effort is the sort of thing that can pay dividends down the road. Cutting approval timelines to make sure that shovels can be in the ground within two years or five years, or whatever the timeframe is is a great thing that can help boost productivity and growth once those shovels start hitting the ground and once the project's complete, whether it's a mine, a port expansion, a nuclear plant, what have you. The problem is, I don't see how any of these things are terribly helpful in 2026.

So I think the real task for this budget is they have to balance three things. They have to balance setting the stage to actually boost future productivity growth. They need to take some measures to fill the gap in aggregate demand that is going to persist into 2026, because I think if the government comes out and their entire budget is focused around measures to boost activity four, five, six years down the line-- again, thinking long term is great, but it doesn't help the economy in 2026.

Greg Bonnell: You want to see something right now.

Andrew Kelvin: So they'll need something to help bridge that gap between when these long-term capital investments start to produce growth and the trouble the economy is facing in adjusting right now.

And the third thing they'll need to do is probably follow through a little bit on some of the "spend less" parts of their slogan. They have talked about cutting the size of the civil service, reducing operating costs, whether it be through more use of technology or reducing consultants, whatever the mode they do is.

They have to balance all these three things, and they don't all pull in the same direction. There's a balance between whether to invest for the long term or the short term. Do want to spend for the long term or the short term? How much new spending do you want to have that is effectively offset by operating cost reductions? Because there is no free cost cutting. Anytime you reduce operating costs for a government, that does have negative implications for the economy. Maybe it's not one for one. There is no pure dead weight that can just be cut here.

Original Post

data.title: Hershey Q3: Protecting Sales Amid Cocoa Price Volatility
data.description:
The Hershey Company (HSY) reported Q3 results on the 30th of October. The confectionery & snack giant reported surprisingly strong sales results despite massive volatility in cocoa prices (CC1:COM) that has continued to weaken the chocolate industry’s performance. Hershey’s brands are clearly performing well. At the same time, Hershey's profitability has clearly been a compromise to maintain sales.

I upheld a Hold rating in my previous March article on the stock, titled “Hershey: Cocoa Price Turbulence Continues.” The stock has since lost -6% of its value, underperforming the S&P 500’s 22% gain.

Hershey’s Q3 Showed Strong Sales Despite Cocoa Inflation

Hershey reported very strong sales in Q3. Revenues came in at $3.18 billion, up by 6.2% year-on-year organically. The pace is above Hershey’s 4.7% revenue CAGR from 2002 to 2024; considering surging cocoa prices that have continued to weaken demand for chocolate, the performance is extremely good. The topline beat Wall Street’s consensus by $60 million with strength across Hershey’s segments.

The most important segment, North America Confectionery, showed 5.2% organic revenue growth to $2.62 billion. The performance reflects an approximated 7% increase in pricing as Hershey has raised prices to account for cocoa inflation, only slightly offset by a small -1% decline in sales volume.

Despite the decline, the segment’s sales volume performance is very strong in my opinion – I also covered Mondelez International, Inc.'s (MDLZ) Q3 results, noting a much more significant -4.6% sales volume decline for the competitor. Mondelez noted higher than expected demand elasticity in the face of price increases, but Hershey’s demand has remained very resilient despite similar pricing actions. Hershey noted a more than 10 basis point retail market share gain in prepared remarks with strength in the Jolly Rancher, Hershey, Cadbury, and Reese’s brands. Product innovation has driven strong retail-level sales, highlighting Hershey's strong brand portfolio.

North America Salty Snacks also had a strong performance; the segment’s sales grew by 10.0% to $321 million, reflecting a massive 11 percentage point sales volume gain. Hershey’s promotional timing, media investments, and product innovation drove the segment’s good performance.

Hershey's revenues also performed well in other markets; the International segment showed 12.1% revenue growth to $245 million, reflecting a 7% pricing increase and 6% growth in sales volume. Shipment timings in Europe and Mexico did contribute a part of the good volume gain as shipments moved from Q4 to Q3; underlying consumption seems to still have been subdued due to demand elasticity.

Hershey does note that the company has had a disappointing early Halloween performance, related by the company to warmer weather and seasonality effects. The overall sales signal from the Q3 report was still strong; on top of a strong Q3 across segments, Hershey raised the 2025 sales growth outlook to 3% from at least 2% previously.

Margins Have Been a Compromise

Hershey’s margins suffered massively in Q3 due to significantly higher cocoa prices – profitability has been a clear compromise as the industry’s pricing power is clearly limited in the face of demand elasticity. The adjusted gross margin showed an 850 basis point decline to 31.8%, reflecting a mix of higher cocoa prices and tariffs. Higher input costs were not even nearly offset by Hershey’s price actions. Mondelez did show an even more significant 1010 basis point gross margin drop in Q3.

Unlike Mondelez, though, Hershey didn’t manage SG&A as prudently – Hershey’s operating expenses grew by 1.5% year-on-year. Adjusted operating income ended up declining by -35.4% to $423 million. The quarter’s $1.30 adjusted EPS still beat Wall Street’s consensus by $0.24 due to already subdued expectations in the current inflationary operating environment.

Profitability issues shift the focus to cocoa deflation. As I also wrote in my article on Mondelez, cocoa prices have started to fall back due to improved crops. Cocoa futures stand at $6000 per tonne at the time of writing, at less than half the December 2024 peak. The 2025/26 season is expected to already show a cocoa supply surplus; while cocoa prices remain significantly high, recent months’ deflation should start to provide a pathway for a margin recovery.

Hershey’s earnings recovery is still likely to be very gradual, being largely dependent on competitors’ pricing, new developments in the cocoa market, and consumers’ demand elasticity going forward.

Hershey’s Valuation Has a Fair Margin of Safety

I updated my discounted cash flow (DCF) model for Hershey. I very slightly raised my revenue estimates, now implying a 2024-2034 CAGR of 2.7%. I now estimate the EBIT margin to stabilize at 21% from 2029 forward, suggesting a margin recovery in the 2026-2028 period due to cocoa deflation.

Hershey’s cash flow conversion should stay healthy.

The estimates put Hershey’s fair value at $210.9, 23% above the stock price at the time of writing. I believe that the estimated upside constitutes a fair margin of safety, as cocoa price volatility remains a short- to mid-term threat to earnings.

The fair value estimate is up from $194.8 previously.

CAPM

The DCF model uses a cost of capital [WACC] of 5.91%, derived from a capital asset pricing model:

I estimate a low 3.82% interest rate, annualized from Hershey’s Q3 interest expenses and debt. I again assume quite a modest 15% long-term debt-to-equity ratio.

For cost of equity, I use the 10-year bond yield of 4.09% as the risk-free rate. The equity risk premium of 4.62% is Professor Aswath Damodaran’s most recent July estimate for the US. I have kept the beta estimate at 0.45. With a liquidity premium of 0.2%, the cost of equity stands at 6.37% and the WACC at 5.91%.

Takeaway

Hershey reported strong sales in Q3 as consumer demand stayed surprisingly resilient amid significant cocoa inflation. The company’s main brands are performing strongly. Yet, the quarter also underlines the industry’s struggles; margins were again a compromise to protect sales as Hershey’s earnings plummeted. Recent months’ cocoa deflation should start to rebound earnings, but at an uncertain timeframe.

HSY stock has a fair margin of safety in its valuation, and I remain at a Hold rating.

data.title: Microsoft: Q1 Earnings Were Overshadowed By Bigger Events
data.description:
Microsoft (MSFT) just reported its Q1 2026 earnings, and in spite of what appears to be a good quarter, the stock's initial reaction is negative. This, however, tells us next to nothing about expected future returns, as there are lots of moving parts within the Artificial Intelligence (AI) space.

On top of all that, heading into Q1 earnings, MSFT was already trading at levels that were incorporating a very optimistic scenario about the future. I won't go into all the details in here, as I already covered this topic three months ago, and since then MSFT has lagged behind the broader tech sector.

With all that in mind, it's not worth spending too much time on the quarterly figures. Instead, investors in MSFT should evaluate quarterly figures with the big picture in-mind and by also incorporating the current valuation within their analysis.

A Brief Look At The Q1 Report

On the surface, the Q1 report came in slightly better than expected, and at first glance nothing within it appears to justify a negative share price reaction.

GAAP earnings and revenue figures were both above the analysts' estimates:

The normalized EPS for the quarter stood at $4.13, which adjusts for the impact of OpenAI investments. Using this normalized number, the earnings surprise was one of the highest in Microsoft's recent history.

One of the main highlights during the quarter was the notable pick-up in commercial remaining performance obligation (RPO), which increased 51% year-on-year. The growth rate was not a complete surprise given the 37% yoy increase during the prior quarter. Nonetheless, it sends a strong signal to investors that demand continues to accelerate.

Commercial remaining performance obligation increased to $392 billion and was up 51% year-over-year.

Source: MSFT Q1 2026 Earnings Transcript

Commercial remaining performance obligation increased to $368 billion, up 37% and 35% in constant currency. Roughly 35% will be recognized in revenue in the next 12 months, up 21% year-over-year.

Source: MSFT Q4 2025 Earnings Transcript

On a segmented basis, growth accelerated in two key segments—consumer cloud and Azure. Growth was primarily driven by higher average revenue per user (ARPU) in the former and stronger demand from the largest customers in the latter.

The outlook for the second quarter of FY 2026 was roughly in line with expectations, with revenue expected to be in the 14% to 16% range. At present, the forward revenue growth estimate by sell-side analysts is almost 15%, which is exactly the mid-point of the range. Gross margin, on the other hand, is expected to drop, but economies of scale would allow MSFT to retain its operating margin flat—something that other peers in the cloud infrastructure space might have a hard time achieving.

(...) we expect revenue of USD 79.5 billion to USD 80.6 billion or growth of 14% to 16%. We expect COGS of USD 26.35 billion to USD 26.55 billion or growth of 21% to 22%. And operating expense of USD 17.3 billion to USD 17.4 billion, growth of 7% to 8%. Operating margins should be relatively flat year-over-year and down sequentially, aligned with historic seasonality.

Source: MSFT Q1 2026 Earnings Transcript

Overall, the Q1 report falls in the category of better-than-anticipated, and the initial negative share price reaction is likely linked to one of the issues that was highlighted a few months ago, namely the beginning of the market to price-in flat operating margins going forward. In spite of all the good news around MSFT in recent months, this is also the reason why the share price remained flat over the past three months as the Nasdaq Composite Index skyrocketed by 16%.

The Big Picture

Nothing has changed over the past few months, and I retain my Hold rating on MSFT due to the issues mentioned in my last analysis. Although the Q1 report was quite good, I anticipate a muted share price reaction to other such earnings releases in the future.

Nevertheless, long-term investors who are willing to forego short-term underperformance and retain a long position in the company should do their best not to miss the forest for the trees. In other words, quarterly numbers could go in either direction in relation to the short-term analysts' estimates, but what truly matters for MSFT now is to remain positioned as a leader in generative AI.

In other words, the section about OpenAI in each earnings release is becoming increasingly important. In the latest report, it was the details given about the new agreement with OpenAI as it undergoes a very important restructuring process.

As the AI landscape evolves, OpenAI and Microsoft needed to alter their existing relationship in order for each one of them to achieve more freedom in certain areas.

In a nutshell, there are two entities: a non-profit one called OpenAI Foundation and a for-profit organization called OpenAI Group PBC. MSFT holds a stake in the latter, which is valued at $135bn. According to MSFT management, the company has already 10x-ed their investments made in the company since 2019.

While the value of MSFT's stake is bound to continue increasing, there have been a number of announcements made regarding the relationship.

Firstly, MSFT would continue to have exclusive IP rights and Azure exclusivity on API (Application Programming Interface) products, and OpenAI has committed to an incremental $250bn investment in Azure services. The new structure also gives MSFT rights to OpenAI's IP and models through 2032 or once an Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) is declared and verified by an expert panel.

Secondly, MSFT can now pursue AGI on its own or with third parties, and the same goes for some products developed by OpenAI. For non-API products, OpenAI will be free to use any other cloud provider as it sees fit.

Lastly, this new organization gives OpenAI some freedom to more easily raise capital and pursue an IPO in the coming years.

Although ChatGPT is still leading by a very wide margin in terms of market share, the competition within the AI-powered products will intensify significantly in the coming years, with all major players announcing significant increases in investments. Thus, the deal with OpenAI could give MSFT a much-needed freedom in further developing its own frontier models. It also opens up the space for other cloud infrastructure vendors to contract workloads from OpenAI.

Conclusion

Microsoft remains one of my favorite picks within the cloud and software sector, alongside my long-time favorite—Oracle (ORCL). Having said that, recent events confirm my fears that the share price does not offer much upside in the near term as investor expectations have already priced-in much of the business momentum. More importantly, however, the latest earnings release shows that quarterly figures are far less relevant for Microsoft's future than the company's strategic positioning in generative AI.

data.title: John Hancock 2025 Lifetime Blend Portfolio Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Market review and outlook

Financial assets delivered strong returns in the quarter, with both stocks and bonds registering gains. A favorable backdrop of positive global growth, falling interest rates across the developed markets, and a lack of pronounced negative news fueled a surge in investors’ appetite for risk. Most notably, the U.S. Federal Reserve (Fed) cut rates by a quarter point in September, and the markets anticipated that additional easing could be in store over the months ahead.

Investors were further cheered by positive corporate earnings reports and the relatively limited initial economic impact from tariffs.

These developments helped propel major equity indexes to a series of all-time highs. The United States led the way higher behind renewed enthusiasm about the artificial intelligence theme and the technology sector more broadly. Small- cap stocks, which benefited from the improving interest rate outlook and investors’ preference for risk, performed particularly well. The emerging markets were another top performer, with China registering an impressive gain amid revived optimism about the country’s economic outlook.

The global fixed-income markets also produced positive returns, reflecting the increasingly favorable shift in Fed policy. Longer-term debt and credit-oriented categories generally provided the best results.

Contributors and detractors

Asset allocation was a slight detractor from the fund’s relative performance in the quarter. An underweight in U.S. large-cap stocks and corresponding overweights in defensive equities, mid caps, and the international markets were the primary drivers of the modest shortfall. On the other hand, an overweight in stocks and underweight in bonds positioned the fund to capitalize on the favorable market environment. Diversification into a real assets portfolio—which was helped by its position in metals and mining stocks—also contributed to performance. An overweight in emerging-market bonds in the fixed-income portfolio was a further positive.

Portfolio changes

Investment conditions remained broadly positive at the close of the period, highlighted by ongoing optimism related to economic conditions and global central bank policy. However, valuations have become fairly full across many areas of the equity and fixed-income markets. With this in mind, we maintain a diversified portfolio designed to hold up through a wide range of possible outcomes. We think it’s better to keep a long-term view rather than trying to chase returns in specific categories. We believe this approach should hold the fund in good stead over time, and we think its merits may become increasingly apparent if the market backdrop becomes less favorable than investors are anticipating.

What you should know before investing

The portfolio’s performance depends on the advisor’s skill in determining asset class allocations, the mix of underlying funds, and the performance of those underlying funds. The portfolio is subject to the same risks as the underlying funds and exchange-traded funds in which it invests: Stocks and bonds can decline due to adverse issuer, market, regulatory, or economic developments; foreign investing, especially in emerging markets, has additional risks, such as currency and market volatility and political and social instability; the securities of small companies are subject to higher volatility than those of larger, more established companies; and high-yield bonds are subject to additional risks, such as increased risk of default. Each portfolio’s name refers to the approximate retirement year of the investors for whom the portfolio’s asset allocation strategy is designed. The portfolios with dates further off initially allocate more aggressively to stock funds. As a portfolio approaches and passes its target date, the allocation will gradually migrate to more conservative, fixed-income funds. The principal value of each portfolio is not guaranteed, and you could lose money at any time, including at, or after, the target date. Liquidity—the extent to which a security may be sold or a derivative position closed without negatively affecting its market value, if at all—may be impaired by reduced trading volume, heightened volatility, rising interest rates, and other market conditions. Hedging and other strategic transactions may increase volatility and result in losses if not successful. Please see the portfolio’s prospectus for additional risks.

The S&P Target Date 2025 Index represents a broadly derived consensus of asset class exposure and glide path for target-date year 2025. The index allocates to equities and fixed income at varying levels according to a predetermined schedule related to the respective target date. Each of the John Hancock Lifetime Indexes is a customized blended index comprising some or all of the following component indices (ordered alphabetically): Bloomberg U.S. Aggregate Bond Index which market-capitalization-weighted index that tracks the performance of U.S. dollar-denominated Brady bonds, Eurobonds, and traded loans issued by sovereign and quasisovereign entities, MSCI Emerging Markets Index which tracks the performance of publicly traded large- and mid-cap emerging-market stocks, MSCI World Energy Index which tracks the performance of publicly traded large- and mid-cap stocks of developed-market energy companies, MSCIWorld ex USA Index which index tracks the performance of publicly traded large- and mid-cap stocks of developed-market companies, excluding the U.S., data.title: SIXG: 5G/6G Play With High Risk, High Reward
data.description:
There are many building blocks of the artificial intelligence revolution, which, as of October 2025, is very much the primary bullish narrative in the market that is keeping investor optimism quite high and equity valuations quite inflated. One of the primary ingredients of the AI economy is technologies that lie at the very nucleus of data transfer, namely connective tech, including solutions for the 5G and 6G networks. And for investors who would like to get exposure to the theme, there are a few vehicles to consider, including the Defiance Connective Technologies ETF (SIXG), a passively managed exchange-traded fund that we will be discussing today.

Basics Of The Defiance Connective Technologies ETF

  • SIXG is a passively managed ETF with an inception date of March 4, 2019.
  • The ETF represents the Technology subclass of the Sector Equity class.
  • Defiance ETFs, LLC is the investment adviser, while Penserra Capital Management LLC is the sub-adviser.
  • As of October 29, 2025, SIXG's assets under management were at $695.36 million, which is almost 5.4x the median AUM for the subclass.
  • SIXG's expense ratio is 0.30%, which is notably below the median ER for the subclass of 0.55%.

What Does SIXG Do?

As we know from the factsheet available on the Defiance ETFs website, SIXG is a thematic, passively managed vehicle offering exposure to "connective technology enablers crucial to the AI revolution," namely, to the 5G and 6G tech that

...provide the infrastructure needed for AI applications that demand high-speed connectivity, low latency, and massive data processing capabilities.

Importantly, established in March 2019, SIXG underwent changes in 2024.

  • First, before July 22, 2024, SIXG was known as the Defiance Next Gen Connectivity ETF and had a ticker FIVG.
  • Second, on September 23, 2024, SIXG started tracking the BlueStar® Connective Technologies Index that replaced the BlueStar 5G Communications Index. The changes were announced by MarketVector Indexes in July 2024.

As explained on page 14 of the prospectus:

Effective September 23, 2024, the Fund’s investment objective changed to track the performance, before fees and expenses, of the BlueStar® Connective Technologies Index. Prior to September 23, 2024, the Fund’s investment objective was to track the total return performance, before fees and expenses, of the BlueStar 5G Communications Index. Performance shown for periods prior to September 23, 2024, is that of the BlueStar 5G Communications Index.

In essence, as we can see in the old and new index universe rules comparison in the press release, while these indices have quite a lot in common, the key differences are that the connective tech index also includes companies involved with "the rollout of 5G, or 6G networks," while the previous one was focused on the 5G networks only. Plus, "satellite-based internet technology/providers" was added to the universe.

Still, investors should understand that although the indices have rather similar premises, the performance that SIXG delivered prior to the strategy change, though certainly of use and not to be ignored, should be treated with caution, as it is not necessarily indicative of the ETF's potential.

For context, my calculations show that the SIXG portfolio as of October 27, 2025, has just a 68.8% overlap with the FIVG portfolio as of October 18, 2022. Moreover, it is quite notable that the basket became substantially leaner, with 50 equities vs. 86 as of October 2022.

How Is The Index Calibrated?

As of October 2025, SIXG tracks the BlueStar® Connective Technologies Index, which features a modified market cap weighting scheme.

As explained by the ETF, this index is composed of

... companies whose business activity, products, or services meet the technical standards for, are used in the development of, or are otherwise instrumental in the rollout of 5G, or 6G networks, and other connective technologies...

To qualify, they must generate no less than 50% of their revenues from a rather vast group of technologies that are detailed on page 9 of the prospectus:

The Fund defines Connective Technology Companies to include: (i) manufacturers of core carrier grade networking equipment, including cellular antennas, routers and related semiconductor devices, (ii) satellite-based internet technology manufacturers and providers, (iii) mobile network operators (“MNOs”), (iv) enhanced mobile broadband chips and smart phone manufacturers, (v) manufacturers of new radio technology, wireless network test and optimization equipment, and cloud computing equipment, (vi) manufacturers and providers of software defined networking or network functions virtualization - including companies that focus on network/cloud analytics and monitoring platforms, and (vii) cell tower or data center real estate investment trusts (“REITs”).

What Returns Has SIXG Been Capable Of Delivering?

Let us look at the returns the ETF delivered before and after its strategy was refocused from the 5G communications to the connective tech.

First, from March 5, 2019, to September 22, 2024, SIXG has considerably underperformed the overall market as represented by the iShares Core S&P 500 ETF (IVV) as well as the Invesco QQQ Trust ETF (QQQ).

Looking at the risk metrics for the April 2019–August 2024 period, we see that SIXG had the highest volatility (measured using standard deviation) compared to QQQ and IVV, while it captured over 110% of IVV's downside.

Metric SIXG IVV QQQ

Downside Capture Ratio 110.05% 100% 108.27%

Data from Portfolio Visualizer. IVV was selected as a benchmark by the author

At the same time, while its maximum drawdown in 2022 was quite steep, it did a little bit better than the Nasdaq 100 ETF.

Second, as of October 29, 2025, since September 23, 2024, SIXG has generated a fairly robust total return, in stark contrast to the previous period, solidly beating both QQQ and IVV, as well as its peers, the First Trust Indxx NextG ETF (NXTG) and the AXS Esoterica NextG Economy ETF (WUGI).

So over the October 2024–September 2025 period, while SIXG's maximum drawdown (delivered in April 2025 during the tariff drama) was the weakest in the group, its upside capture ratio of over 192% looks much more appealing.

Data from Portfolio Visualizer. IVV was selected as a benchmark by the author

All in all, SIXG has a rather expectable performance for a vehicle heavy in growth stocks: it does excellent in bull markets and underperforms dismally when bears dictate the rules.

Who Is SIXG For, And How Does It Fit In A Portfolio?

SIXG might be an ETF of choice for investors seeking to profit from the 5G and 6G themes and who believe that passively managed vehicles targeting the communication sector, like the Communication Services Select Sector SPDR® ETF Fund (XLC), simply do not offer enough exposure to them.

Sure, they should be very fond of the growth factor and have little to no interest in value stocks (they are still present in SIXG but have a rather modest impact on its returns), and understand the risks that high achievers with generous valuations come with.

As to the popular core-satellite system, SIXG looks like a decent satellite holding, with a core of the portfolio possibly being either IVV or any other S&P 500 ETF like the Vanguard S&P 500 ETF (VOO), the SPDR® S&P 500® ETF (SPY), and the SPDR® Portfolio S&P 500® ETF (SPLG), or QQQ.

Importantly, position sizing is always key when building a tech-focused portfolio from various thematic blocks, as high-beta baskets of growthier stocks can deliver quite sensitive losses when conditions turn gloomy (marked by too high inflation, shifts in monetary policy from dovish to hawkish regimes, an overall weak macro environment, etc.). So investors should have a clear understanding of what share of their portfolios they can allocate to higher-risk names and what they are planning to do if these stocks enter a long period of losses.

For context, in 2022 (even though the strategy was a little different back then, there is still some overlap with the current one), the ETF, traded with a ticker FIVG, delivered a maximum drawdown of 30.8% (vs. IVV's 23.93%), and its loss for the year was 27.25% (vs. IVV's loss of 18.16%).

How Is SIXG Built?

As of October 27, 2025, there were 52 holdings in the SIXG portfolio, including 50 equities, the First American Government Obligations Fund 12/01/2031 (FGXXX), and cash & other, with the latter two accounting for 0.24%.

The top holding was Apple Inc. (AAPL), a tech heavyweight that hardly needs a lengthy introduction, with 5.38% weight, and the smallest was Kingsoft Cloud Holdings Ltd (KC), a Beijing-based "leading cloud service provider in China," with a 1.19% weight.

A considerable number of SIXG's holdings are S&P 500 constituents.

Parameter SIXG IVV
Companies present both in the SIXG and IVV portfolios 45.77% 20.70%

Calculated by the author using data from the ETFs and Seeking Alpha

There is some overlap with QQQ, though a modest one.

Parameter SIXG QQQ
Companies present both in the SIXG and QQQ portfolios 28.78% 34.32%

Calculated by the author using data from the ETFs and Seeking Alpha

Key Ten SIXG Holdings

The main ten holdings in the SIXG portfolio account for about 35.8% of the net assets.

Prepared by the author using data from Seeking Alpha and the ETFs

SIXG Sector Mix

The direct result of SIXG's focus on the 5G and 6G themes is that its sector mix is materially different from that of the S&P 500 ETF.

Sector SIXG, as of October 27, 2025 IVV, as of October 24, 2025
Information Technology 83.6% 35.3%

Created by the author using data from the ETFs and Seeking Alpha

  • First, there are just four sectors represented (there are 11 sectors in the GICS system), namely IT, communication, industrials, and real estate.
  • Second, SIXG is massively overweight in IT, has slightly larger exposure to real estate, and is underweight in industrials, while the weights of the communication sector in its portfolio and IVV's are nearly on par (SIXG has just a 0.21% larger allocation).

SIXG Factor Mix

The key thing investors should understand about SIXG's factor story is that its portfolio consists mainly of high achievers that are mostly priced at a premium to the market (there are exceptions like Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) and AT&T Inc. (T), but their impact on the weighted average figures is modest). Also, these high achievers are quite volatile, with 43% of the portfolio allocated to names with a 24-month beta of 1.5 or higher, as per my calculations. High P/E plus high-growth plus high beta means excellent returns in bull markets. In bear markets and corrections, this is a recipe for disaster.

Metrics SIXG IVV
Market Cap, $ Billion 582.85 1,397
Adjusted EY 2.78% 3.49%
Adjusted P/S 9.60 9.40
Adjusted EV/EBITDA 25.37 22.23
Revenue Fwd 12.99% 14.00%
